file_content.text: You better be ready to get started on your trials immediately.
I want to do well.
Please explain.
I like that.
I understand.
Where is the tomb?
It will do.
Good, you've returned. You seem to be in one piece. Tell me, how do you like your new blade?
What are you doing, Father? I only just got my warblade, and I've been here six months.
I have my reasons, Eskella. And you will not breathe a word of this to anyone. Do you hear?
Acolyte, this is Eskella, my daughter. She's one of the advanced students here. On her way to becoming Sith. If she minds herself.
I'll keep quiet about your new charge, Father. But I won't be there if whatever you're planning blows up in your face.
Nice to meet you.
Nepotism has its advantages, I see.
Riding daddy's coattails, huh?
She won't be a Sith for long if she doesn't.
She better mind me.
I'll take such threats from him, newcomer, but not from a wet-behind-the-ears infant like you.
Just because my father has obviously selected you for some special assignment, doesn't mean you can disrespect me and not risk the consequences.
Respect is something you earn, Eskella.
Who are you to me?
I'll take that risk.
My mistake. I meant nothing by it.
I apologize.
No. I'm... amazed. I knew you were strong in the Force, but not... like this.
You're more than ready to challenge Vemrin. Baras... won't be able to deny that now.
He'll have the satisfaction... of my death, but I die knowing my... success. Go ahead... end this.
You fought bravely, overseer. Die with your head held high.
You fought well. [Kill Tremel]
You're getting ahead of yourself. I only need your hand.
I just need your hand.
What? Wait... I think I understand.
Baras demands my hand... proof of my death? I don't want your pity, acolyte.
It's not pity. I don't want you to die.
I'm saving you.
That's the deal. Take it or leave it.
Your choice.
I'm a credit to the dark side... my cause... is just. You can see clearly, even if Baras cannot.
Take my hand.
Argh! Ha! Well, that didn't tickle! I'll rest and then leave Korriban... covertly.
As it should be.
You'll live.
Of course. Goodbye, acolyte. Rid the Sith of that plague Vemrin. My hopes... lie with you.
A sad end.
Agreed. But as long as you live... there is hope. Cast Vemrin out, and the final triumph will be ours. Goodbye.
Fine. Have it your way, death it is.
Okay, then die. [Kill Tremel]
You are my greatest kill to date. I will rejoice in your blood!
You sicken me. [Kill Tremel]
Farewell, acolyte. The purity of the Sith... lies with you.
I didn't expect to see you again so soon. Has Baras sent you back to me?
He wants you dead.
Your instincts are sharp, overseer. Baras ordered me to kill you.
Regretfully, we must fight.
Today's my lucky day. Baras granted my wish--I get to kill you now.
Happily, I get to kill you.
Then I have been outplayed. Baras has the authority, but I did not think he would do something this overt.
Either I die or he forces me to kill you and to destroy my own plan. A master stroke.
Very well. You have your orders, acolyte. Know that it gives me no pleasure to kill you.
What makes you so sure you're going to kill me?
You're certain you'll win?
You're strong, acolyte, as strong as any I've seen come through the Academy. But you're not Sith yet.
If you say so.
Hold on, it doesn't have to come to this, Tremel.
There is another way.
Do not hedge now. This is the way of the Sith.
I'll try to make your end quick and painless. It's the least I can do.
Darth Baras has summoned you. That's not something you wait to respond to. Go to his chambers, now.
The beast of Marka Ragnos was a great source of dark energy here on Korriban. When it was slain, there was a tremor in the Force.
Darth Baras felt that tremor and has become aware of you. He demands an audience.
Tell me what to expect, overseer.
Prepare me for it.
Do you think I'm ready for this?
Am I up to it?
It doesn't matter what I think. Ready or not, you must face him now.
Good. I've been waiting for this for a long time.
It's about time.
After meeting him, you may find yourself wishing you had more time to prepare.
Baras is a serious man but a master of deception. Everything he does and says is calculated.
He will attempt to trip you up, test your nature, get to the heart of who you are. Always take him seriously. And I mean always.
I can handle Darth Baras.
No problem.
Baras is usually the one doing the handling.
Thanks for the warning.
You worry too much, Tremel.
Stop fretting.
I just wish we'd had a little more time.
We might not speak again, acolyte. You're the best chance of stopping Vemrin. If you fail, I doubt there will be another strong enough. Good luck.
Take care of yourself.
I'll succeed.
You've just been holding me back. Good riddance.
Just get out of my way.
Just be sure you're at your best, and do exactly what he says.
Meet Darth Baras in his chambers. And hurry, he won't take kindly to waiting.
We must speak quickly, acolyte, there isn't much time. I may have made a slight miscalculation.
Whatever it is, I'm sure I can handle the consequences.
I'm not worried.
The timetable for finding out what you can handle has been sped up.
Tell me.
I'm not going to like this, am I?
Uh-oh.
You've been itching to get into action, now's your chance.
The beast in the tomb of Marka Ragnos awaits you. Don't delay.
Now, we must hurry to your next trial. Every moment that passes we risk discovery before we're ready.
As you say, overseer. Tell me what I must do next.
Yes, sir.
If you fail, it certainly won't be for lack of enthusiasm. I'll give you that.
I think I'm ready now, but hurry up and talk.
If I have to.
I'll be the one who decides when you're ready, acolyte.
You're filled with fear, Tremel. It's embarrassing.
Don't be such a coward.
Fear is not the enemy, acolyte. If used correctly, it is a source of strength.
You'll need to channel your rage to survive this task. It's designed to test your endurance and skill in combat.
In the caverns of Marka Ragnos is the beast he left to guard his legacy. Go there, sit among the flames, and wait for the beast to come for you.
You think that's enough information? How about you tell me about this beast?
Shouldn't I know more?
All you need to know is that it's ferocious and bloodthirsty, and in no way is it a trial for a normal acolyte.
It will be a simple task.
Don't be rash. Defeating this creature will take your best effort.
I will unleash my fury.
Hold nothing back. This creature is doom itself.
Return to the Valley of the Dark Lords and find the tomb of Marka Ragnos. I'll see you when the beast is slain. Good luck.
Is this everything?
Everything Lord Renning was able to obtain, yes.
Then run back to your master in the beast pens, before I cut you in half.
Yes, of course. I'll leave at once.
And tell Renning not to offer my pupil any chances to "aid his research." I know how his mind works.
I will convey your message.
It may be too late for that, but I will convey your message.
Sorry to make you wait, acolyte. These interruptions are incredibly annoying.
My task is complete.
I succeeded.
Good. I can't get wrapped up in petty concerns. I must keep my focus on the larger task at hand.
I can't believe you tolerate interruptions.
Why put up with him?
There was a time I would have beheaded that peon, but now....
You're lucky I'm tolerating you.
You're taxing me.
You'd be nothing without me. Not yet, anyway.
On to the business at hand: your test in the jails. First, the assassin, Solentz. She attempted to kill an Imperial spy but was unaware of her client's affiliation.
You killed her in cold blood. Why?
She admitted her guilt--didn't even have the sense to lie.
I got a confession.
I understand the reasoning, but that was not the best choice.
She failed her assignment. I do not abide failures.
She was a screwup.
No. But you can always turn someone's failure into personal profit.
I didn't like the look of her. You have a problem with that?
Her looks.
Why did you grant her trial by combat?
She had a warrior's spirit. Even after prison and torture, she remained unbroken.
She earned it.
All the more reason to keep her alive.
Just for kicks. It amused me. You have a problem with that?
For the fun of it.
She thought she was strong and special. It was the best way to teach her how impotent she is.
To put her in her place.
Little good the humbling will do with her dead.
Never waste a potential resource. A trained assassin who demonstrated fortitude and amorality? The Empire could have utilized her skills.
You assigned her to Imperial Intelligence. I commend you, that was excellent thinking. Never waste a potential resource.
Thank you, overseer. I'm glad you approve.
Good.
What's more important is that Darth Baras would approve.
Of course. The answer was obvious.
No kidding.
Obvious to you, but not to many who have come before you.
I just figured, let the Imperials deal with her insolence.
I just passed the buck.
Whatever the reasoning, the choice was exactly what Darth Baras would respect.
Now, Devotek, the former warrior. He wanted combat, but you struck him down. Perfect. The man was utterly useless.
I do not ever choose to waste my time.
Utterly.
I took no pleasure in killing him.
It meant nothing.
And why would you? It's like taking out the trash--you just do it, you don't think about it.
I just did it for the fun of it.
It was whimsy.
Well, the instinct was spot on.
Once something is used up, it should be eradicated.
Now, Devotek, the failed warrior. Why grant his wish for a trial by combat?
I did it out of respect for his service. He used to be a potent warrior.
To honor his past.
We don't have time to honor yesterday's accomplishments.
I needed to discover for certain that he was no longer useful.
I wanted to learn his worth.
That holds some merit. But it should have been obvious he was far past any use.
I wanted to show him how ineffective he'd become--and to rub it in his face.
To prove his uselessness.
So glad you enjoyed yourself but such a petty exercise wastes time, something we have a shortage of at the moment.
Now, the failed warrior, Devotek. He begged you to let him die fighting. You left him languishing in his cell. Why?
I thought maybe time will reawaken the lion inside him.
He might bounce back.
It should have been obvious to you that his fire cannot be rekindled.
Anything else would have been too much effort. He's not worthy of my time or blade.
I couldn't be bothered.
Why spare him the indignation? Death would only relieve his suffering.
He should live in anguish.
So now we continue to waste resources housing him?
Devotek was an utter waste of space. Once something is no longer useful, it should be eradicated. Remember that.
Now the forger who maintained his innocence. You refused to deal with him. Explain.
We have better things to do with our time than deal with the likes of him, right?
Not worth my consideration.
Wrong. Sloppy and unacceptable.
I ignore gnats and puddles of water. Must I explain that as well?
He's an insect.
Yes, in fact you do. Deciding not to engage is sloppy.
I didn't deal with him, and I'm not going to justify myself to you either.
I don't have to explain it.
If you plan on advancing here, you'd better drop that attitude, acolyte.
You left the issue in limbo. Things fall through the cracks when they're disregarded. No matter how insignificant something seems, be definitive.
Lastly, the forger you sent back for more torture even though he seemed innocent. A strong decision. Leave no stone unturned.
Exactly.
And what if it turns out he truly is innocent?
We should know the truth.
The ripple from even a tiny stone can flow a great distance.
I pay attention to detail.
Well, well, look who just turned deep and insightful.
It's always best to know beyond any doubt. After all, what is one man's sanity or life versus the fate of the Empire?
Now, the last prisoner--the forger. Letting him go was highly questionable. Explain yourself.
It's folly to waste time tormenting an innocent man.
He didn't do it.
Keeping or killing him would be meaningless. Nothing would be gained by either.
Other options were pointless.
And what if I refuse to explain myself to you?
I'm done justifying.
Then you're not going to advance very far, are you?
Innocent or not, he leaves here with firsthand knowledge of our facilities and procedures. It's potentially compromising to have him floating about the galaxy.
You must always be thinking, and considering every angle. Aside from a strong and skilled sword arm, that will be what impresses Darth Baras the most.
In each situation, you failed to find the path of the thinking Sith. If we have any hope of you supplanting Vemrin in Darth Baras's eyes, you must improve quickly.
Hmm, each time, each prisoner, you made the best possible decision. You may yet be able to challenge Vemrin for Darth Baras's attention. To celebrate: a small reward.
Thank you very much, overseer.
Very nice of you.
Thank yourself, acolyte. It's performances like this that might just beat the extreme odds we're facing.
Of course I got it all right. I am perfection.
I had no doubt.
We'll see. Try to remain levelheaded. All it takes is one misstep and you're dead.
Then I'm ready. Let's make our move.
No time like the present.
Don't be so hasty, acolyte. There's more that must be done before we expose you to Baras.
You're beginning to understand what it means to be Sith, but you're far from being able to impress Darth Baras.
I'll try harder, overseer. I promise.
I'm up to it.
If you don't, you're doomed. Remember that.
I'm not worried about impressing Baras.
I don't care.
Impress him or die. Those are really the only choices you have.
Excuse me if I have yet to achieve perfection.
You expect too much.
Perfection might be the only thing that saves you.
Because I forced you into the Academy ahead of schedule, Darth Baras will be predisposed to judging you severely. And by severely, I mean fatally.
Stop wasting time. Go to the jails, speak with the jailer, and pass judgment on the three prisoners waiting there.
You must proceed to your next trial immediately. I want you to interrogate three prisoners in the Academy jails and decide their fates.
Consider each criminal's story carefully. The decisions you make will be scrutinized, so let your passions guide your judgments.
Of course.
Scrutinized? Who presumes to judge my actions? You?
That doesn't sound acceptable.
Of course. When Darth Baras catches wind of you, it's going to be my neck on the line as much as yours.
You better send someone to clean up after me.
Those criminals are doomed.
The slave pens are right there. They have mops.
Go to the Academy prison. Speak to head jailer Knash and return to me after you've passed judgment on the prisoners.
I hope it's thirsty. I plan on drowning it.
It will carve destruction.
Take a look. I've already bloodied it.
It killed k'lor'slugs.
Yes. Yes, Father.
No doubt my father has plans for you, newcomer. You must be something special indeed.
I hope to prove your father's faith in me is well placed.
I'll earn that distinction.
Well, aren't you the perfect little soldier?
That will do, Eskella. Thank you for the visit.
Perhaps someday, I can show you how special.
[Flirt] Find out for yourself.
I'm sure father hasn't brought you here to flirt with me, boy.
I like to think so.
Indeed I am.
Awfully full of yourself, I see.
Jealousy doesn't become you, Eskella.
You wish you were me.
Me? Jealous? That's a laugh.
I am strong with the Force, newcomer.
Enough, both of you. Eskella, thank you for the visit.
Good of you to stop by, daughter.
Don't mind her. She's just sore that I'm keeping secrets. She growls but she's loyal.
I wouldn't trust her if I were you.
I'm not so sure.
Don't worry about me, acolyte. No Sith trusts completely. Even with kin.
If you trust her, why keep secrets?
Why leave her in the dark?
It's for her own good.
I don't get involved in family matters.
I'm not interested.
Good. Keep your mind on the tasks at hand.
Now, I thought I heard Vemrin's voice in the adjacent chamber before you arrived. Did he make his move so soon?
It was nothing I couldn't handle.
I stood up to him.
He just introduced himself to me.
It was nothing.
If he didn't attack, he must not fully comprehend the threat you represent. Good, good.
Yeah. I hate him already. I look forward to ending his miserable existence.
Can't wait to shut him up.
If things go well, you will have that satisfaction someday.
Still, I'd hoped we'd have more time. Vemrin's not the type to sniff around for too long before trying to take a bite.
Why don't you tell me what the problem is with Vemrin?
Bring me up to speed.
It's better that you understand anyway.
Why are you so afraid of this guy?
He scares you.
I'm afraid of what he represents.
Let him try to bite me.
I'll bite back.
You might get a disease from that mongrel.
In a drive for sheer numbers, the criteria for Academy admittance has been relaxed. Now anyone with Force sensitivity is allowed entrance.
Vemrin is mixed blood. The invisible rot eating at the foundation of the Empire. He must not be allowed to advance.
So, please, just let me stop him.
I'm ready now.
You're not ready. Plain and simple.
So, you're an elitist snob.
You look down on him.
You say that like it's a bad thing. It's the Sith way. Only the best, only the most pure, should be good enough.
So, stop him yourself.
Do something about it.
Unfortunately, Vemrin's caught the eye of Darth Baras, one of the most influential Sith Lords. He's being groomed to be Baras's new apprentice.
As Darth Baras's apprentice, the power at Vemrin's fingertips will be considerable. He could change the Sith for the worse.
I should be Baras's apprentice.
Should be me.
I want that power!
Sounds intoxicating.
What's my role in this?
When the time is right, we will make our move. But we must be patient.
I wasn't overseeing Vemrin's trials, otherwise I would have found a way to cast him out. Now, the matter must be handled delicately.
Hurry and secure a Sith warblade from the tomb of Ajunta Pall. There is much that must be done.
At last, you've arrived. Good, good. There is much to do and every moment is critical.
I am at your disposal, my lord.
Command me.
Good. Your attitude is already well adjusted.
I'm always ready. Just tell me what I need to do.
Get to it.
I see you don't waste time with pleasantries. Good.
What are you babbling about, old man?
You're making no sense.
Respect me, acolyte. I know you have questions. Answers will come as I see fit.
I'm Overseer Tremel. For decades, I've administered the trials that prove who is and is not worthy to join the Sith Order.
The trials are a chance to weed out the weak. Those who face them either survive and become Sith, or die.
Good. I risked a lot to make this happen.
I think I'll take the first option.
I'm a survivor.
I didn't bring you here for levity.
Mark my words, I am destined to be Sith.
This is in my blood.
It wasn't destiny that brought you here.
Yes, you are here and ahead of schedule because of me. I expect you to obey.
I'm at your service, overseer.
Not a problem.
I'll tell you only what you need to know.
What if I don't want to be your lackey?
Why should I?
You have no choice.
You face your trials, you serve me, and I will make you the most powerful acolyte here.
Good, then I shouldn't have to repeat myself.
Why am I skeptical?
Not sure I'm buying this.
Have a critical edge, but recognize who is on your side.
You had better be able to deliver that, Tremel.
Be sure you do.
Leave your doubt at the door--there's no room for it in here. And no time to waste.
The trials themselves are difficult enough, but they are hardly the greatest threat you face.
There's an acolyte here named Vemrin. He's your enemy, and he will try to kill you. We must prepare you.
How is it I already have an enemy?
But I just got here.
All you need to know is that you are a threat to him, and he to you. We'll make sure you can stand up to that threat.
Maybe he can be reasoned with?
I'll try to talk to him.
There are no amends to make with a... creature like Vemrin. We must strengthen your bond with the Force to match his.
Let him try. I'll destroy him.
Then he'll die.
With my guidance, someday you'll destroy all your enemies.
That practice sword you've arrived with is insufficient--the blade of lesser acolytes. You need a dominating weapon.
In the tomb of Ajunta Pall, there's an old armory. A strong Sith warblade awaits you there.
Sounds too easy. What's the catch?
It can't be that simple.
Good. You're already thinking.
If I'm to be Sith, I should have a lightsaber!
What's this warblade nonsense?
Someday you may wield the weapon of the masters, but not today.
The tomb is thick with k'lor'slugs--deadly, savage creatures. Be speedy but careful. They've been the end of many an acolyte.
If they lack the instinct to avoid me, I'll feed them their heads.
I'll destroy them all.
The only thing they don't eat is each other.
Then I'll have something in common with the beasts.
I will be too.
They're mindless. Try not to emulate that trait.
The exit here leads to the Valley of the Dark Lords, where the tomb can be found.
Once you acquire the warblade, I suggest you spend some time in the tomb bloodying it. Then come to me in my chambers in the Academy.
You're in the wrong room. I have business with my acolyte.
